title: Mixed Tension Migraine
author: Kathryn Whitbourne

content: You may have heard the terms “mixed tension headache,” "chronic daily headache," “chronic tension headache,” “mixed headache syndrome,” or “tension-vascular headache” before.

Experts group all of these into a syndrome called chronic daily headache (CDH). These are different kinds of headaches that happen often -- more than 15 days each month for at least 3 months. They can be migraine or tension headaches . Some come on when you take too much headache medication.

content_blocks.text: You may have heard the terms “mixed tension headache,” "chronic daily headache," “chronic tension headache,” “mixed headache syndrome,” or “tension-vascular headache” before.

Experts group all of these into a syndrome called chronic daily headache (CDH). These are different kinds of headaches that happen often -- more than 15 days each month for at least 3 months. They can be migraine or tension headaches . Some come on when you take too much headache medication.

sections.heading: Tension Headache
content: This is the most common type of headache. They usually cause:
Some tension headaches last 30 minutes, others can last for a week. Experts aren’t sure what causes them, but stress is a common trigger.
bullets: Steady, dull pain, often across your forehead or the back of your head
Tightness or pressure -- some people say it feels like you have a band across your head
Soreness in your scalp, neck, and shoulder muscles

content_blocks.text: This is the most common type of headache. They usually cause:
associated_bullets: Steady, dull pain, often across your forehead or the back of your head
Tightness or pressure -- some people say it feels like you have a band across your head
Soreness in your scalp, neck, and shoulder muscles

content_blocks.text: Some tension headaches last 30 minutes, others can last for a week. Experts aren’t sure what causes them, but stress is a common trigger.

sections.heading: Migraine Headache
content: If you get a migraine, you'll probably have:

Most of these type headaches last around hours, but some can stick around much longer. You might get them every day, or just one or two times a year. A visual aura (flashing lights, blind spots, or wavy lines) might happen before your headache starts. Doctors don’t know what causes them, but your genes and environment seem to play a role. Many people have a family history of migraines. Common triggers include:
bullets: Pounding or throbbing pain that may be on one side of your head or all over
Sensitivity to light, noise, and smells

content_blocks.text: If you get a migraine, you'll probably have:
associated_bullets: Pounding or throbbing pain that may be on one side of your head or all over
Sensitivity to light, noise, and smells

content_blocks.text: Most of these type headaches last around hours, but some can stick around much longer. You might get them every day, or just one or two times a year. A visual aura (flashing lights, blind spots, or wavy lines) might happen before your headache starts. Doctors don’t know what causes them, but your genes and environment seem to play a role. Many people have a family history of migraines. Common triggers include:

sections.heading: Medication Overuse Headache
content: Most people take some kind of pain reliever like acetaminophen (Panadol, Tylenol ), ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin , Nuprin ),or naproxen ( Aleve , Anaprox , Naprosyn ) to treat their headaches. But if yours are ongoing, you may end up using one of these medications every day. Doing that can make things worse. You might get a " rebound headache ” when the medication wears off. This happens a lot if you're using a pain reliever with caffeine or codeine.

If you have a medication overuse headache, you'll need to stop taking the pain reliever you've been using. Your doctor will tell you how to do this. Your headaches may feel worse at first. But they should get better after about a week. The doctor may prescribe other drugs to help during this time.

This happens a lot if you're using a pain reliever with caffeine or codeine.

If you have a medication overuse headache, you'll need to stop taking the pain reliever you've been using. Your doctor will tell you how to do this. Your headaches may feel worse at first. But they should get better after about a week. The doctor may prescribe other drugs to help during this time.

sections.heading: Diagnosing Headache Type
content: The doctor will ask you what your headache feels like. They'll also ask how often you get it, what you've been taking for it, and how long. You might have more than one type at the same time. If the doctor thinks some of your symptoms seem strange, they may order a CT scan or MRI .

content_blocks.text: The doctor will ask you what your headache feels like. They'll also ask how often you get it, what you've been taking for it, and how long. You might have more than one type at the same time. If the doctor thinks some of your symptoms seem strange, they may order a CT scan or MRI .

sections.heading: Things to Look For
content: Most headaches aren’t dangerous. But they can be a sign of something serious in your brain, like bleeding or inflammation. Seek emergency medical care if your headache:
Call 911 if you have these symptoms along with a headache:
bullets: Comes on suddenly and gets really painful very quickly
Comes on after heavy exercise or a small injury
Feels really bad, different from what you felt before
Seizure, a personality change, or passing out

content_blocks.text: Most headaches aren’t dangerous. But they can be a sign of something serious in your brain, like bleeding or inflammation. Seek emergency medical care if your headache:
associated_bullets: Comes on suddenly and gets really painful very quickly

Feels really bad, different from what you felt before

content_blocks.text: Call 911 if you have these symptoms along with a headache:
associated_bullets: Seizure, a personality change, or passing out

sections.heading: Treatment
content: You can treat a tension headache with aspirin or other over-the-counter (OTC) pain relievers. One with caffeine may get rid of the pain quicker. try not to use them more than 9 days per month, or two doses per headache. Talk to your doctor if you’re still in pain after taking these medications.

OTC pain relievers can help with migraine pain, too, along with prescription drugs. These are usually aspirin or acetaminophen mixed with codeine or caffeine. It may also have an anti-emetic to ease nausea.

content_blocks.text: You can treat a tension headache with aspirin or other over-the-counter (OTC) pain relievers. One with caffeine may get rid of the pain quicker. try not to use them more than 9 days per month, or two doses per headache. Talk to your doctor if you’re still in pain after taking these medications.

OTC pain relievers can help with migraine pain, too, along with prescription drugs. These are usually aspirin or acetaminophen mixed with codeine or caffeine. It may also have an anti-emetic to ease nausea.

sections.heading: How to Avoid Headaches
content: If you have tension headaches, antidepressants called tricyclics (TCAs) may help. It's not clear how these drugs work, but they seem to ease pain when used in low doses. TCAs also can work for migraines. Your doctor might prescribe these drugs, too:

Lowering your stress level might also help. Stress can cause your body to send out certain brain chemicals that often bring on a headache. A therapist can guide you on how to better manage stress. Biofeedback training teaches you how to control your body’s responses to lower pain, like slowing your heart rate and breathing deeply. Yoga and meditation may also ease your symptoms.
bullets: Calcium channel blockers (which relax the blood vessels)

content: Along with stress management, take these steps to keep headaches from happening:

Everyone has different triggers. Try to keep a headache diary to learn what triggers your headache. Write down what you were doing just before it started. What did you eat or smell? What was the weather like? This may lower the number of headaches you have and your level of pain.
bullets: Cut back on alcohol and caffeine, and quit smoking.

meta_description: What's the difference between a mixed tension migraine and a regular headache or migraine? Learn more about this type of headache and its symptoms today.
